review.title: Landmark Guided Probabilistic Roadmap Queries
review.abstract: A landmark based heuristic is investigated for reducing query phase run-time of the probabilistic roadmap (\PRM) motion planning method. The heuristic is generated by storing minimum spanning trees from a small number of vertices within the \PRM graph and using these trees to approximate the cost of a shortest path between any two vertices of the graph. The intermediate step of preprocessing the graph increases the time and memory requirements of the classical motion planning technique in exchange for speeding up individual queries making the method advantageous in multi-query applications. This paper investigates these trade-offs on \PRM graphs constructed in randomized environments as well as a practical manipulator simulation.We conclude that the method is preferable to Dijkstra's algorithm or the ${\rm A}^*$ algorithm with conventional heuristics in multi-query applications.

sections.heading: II. MOTION PLANNING PROBLEM
sections.text: The following problem of optimal motion planning is addressed: Let Xfree be an open, limited subset of Rd and the set of continuous curves from [0, 1] to Rn. Then let "free" be the subset of "whose image is contained in Xfree. The cost objective is a function c: [0, ∞) that assigns a cost of 170 4.01 886v 1 [cs.R O] 6A pr2 017costs to each curve in Rd. Cost function must be additive in the sense that if two curves meet an initial state of x0, 1, 2 ([0, 1]), then c (0, 1) then c (γ1) ≤ c (γ2). An individual query of motion planning on Xfree is to find a curve that is from an initial state x0, Xfree to a target state xg, Xfree. sections.heading: A. Probabilistic Roadmaps
sections.text: To avoid confusion with curves on Xfree, a path is a sequence of vertices in a diagram {xi}, so that (xi, xi + 1) is an edge in the diagram. Curves on Xfree are approximated using paths in the diagram by associating each edge of the diagram with the line segment between the two vertices that make up the edge. PRM method falls into this category of approximations to the free edge. PRM method [7] is a popular variant of PRM because it creates a sparse diagram with the following property: If x0 and xg belong to a contiguous subset of Xfree, then the probability that the PRM diagram contains a curve that has a free satisfaction curve is < if x0 and xg belong to a contiguous subset of Xfree, then the probability is that the PRM diagram contains a curve that contains a short-term + short-term (short-term), short-term (< short-term) (short-term) (<

sections.heading: III. THE LANDMARK HEURISTIC
sections.text: The resulting heuristics are permissible regardless of cost and environment, making them a very general approach to obtaining a permissible heuristic. However, the idea behind landmark heuristics is as follows: Let d: VPRM · VPRM → [0, ∞] be the function that returns the cost of a shortest path from one vertex of the chart to another; take the value if no path exists. However, it follows from the definition that d satisfies the triangular inequality. Consider a vertex xl ² VPRM that will represent a milestone. Reordering the triangular inequality with xl and x ² g results in | d (xl, xl) − d (xl, g) − d (x, g) a minimal determination of the destination path (x, x).

sections.heading: A. Complexity of the Landmark Heuristic
sections.text: The generation of the function d (·, xl) for a single landmark requires the solution of a single problem for the shortest path from one point to another (·, xl), which can be achieved with the Dijkstra algorithm in O (| VPRM | log (| VPRM |)). From this observation, it emerges that this heuristics is only useful in cases where the number of queries for motion planning evaluated on the PRM chart is greater than the number of queries for the shortest path required for the construction of the heuristic period. (7) The heuristic evaluation of the landmark (7) requires the search for the optimal cost of a landmark 2 · | Vl | x x x x, so that the complexity of (7) is linear in the number of landmarks.

sections.heading: B. Demonstration of the Landmark Heuristic
sections.text: In order to demonstrate the advantages of using the directional heuristics, it was compared with the Dijkstra algorithm and A х with the Euclidean distance euristics in a bug trap environment. A PRM was constructed in the bug trap environment according to algorithm 1 with a density of 1000 vertices per area unit for a total of 69, 272 vertices. Landmark heuristics were then constructed using 100 vertices (0.14% of vertices), which were determined by random sampling from the vertices of the chart. Figure 2 shows the environment and vertices augmented by algorithm A х, using euclidean distance as heuristics and the trend-setting heuristics. The A algorithm with the euclidean distance required 58, 145 iterations and 351ms to find the shortest path; a marginal performance difference compared to the 69, 180 iterations and 334js, which requires only the corner points of the algorithm.

sections.heading: IV. EVALUATION IN RANDOMIZED ENVIRONMENTS
sections.text: Environments with randomly placed obstacles provide a simple and easily reproducible benchmark for motion planning algorithms [9], [10]. In this paper, the degree of disorder in these randomly generated environments is quantified as the probability that the line segment linking two randomly captured points is included in Xfree.

sections.heading: A. Environment Generation
sections.text: A Poisson forest of intensity λ circular obstacles with radius r is used as a random environment. It is simulated using an example window S = [− 1, 1] 2 by scanning the number of obstacles N from the Poisson distributionfN (n) = (λµ (S) ne − λµ (S) n!, (9) and then randomly placing these obstacles on S. The subset of S occupied by the circular obstacles is called Xobs. Then we select Xfree = [− 0.5, 0.5] 2\ Xobs. Embedding Xfree in S simplifies subsequent calculations by eliminating boundary effects of the sample window pass. Let Z1 and Z2 be independent random variables with the even distribution on Xfree, and let the event clearly indicate that the line segment connecting Z1 and Z2 is in Xµ 2. The next probability is the closest derivative to the obstacle µ.

sections.heading: B. Numerical Experiments
sections.text: In order to obtain the results in a reasonable time, parallel experiments were carried out on the central high-performance cluster EULER (Expandable, Environmentally Friendly, Powerful ETH Computer) of the ETH Zurich. Each computing node consists of two 12-core Intel Xeon E5-2680 processors with clock rates between 2.5 and 3.5 GHz. In the first test set, a single random environment was sampled with P (clear) = 0.05. Three PRM diagrams with 40,000, 60,000 and 80,000 vertices were created on this environment. On each PRM, 700 landmark heuristics were constructed, 100 each for landmark sizes | Vl | {10, 30, 50, 70, 90, 110, 130}. Subsequently, a random shortest route query with the PRIV values was created for each Landmark Heuristics.

sections.heading: C. Results
sections.text: The first experiment, summarized in Figure 4, showed how the effectiveness of landmark heuristics varied with a fraction of the vertices assigned to the landmarks, as well as with different graph sizes. We observed a rapid reduction in the iterations required to find a solution in relation to Dijkstra's algorithm, with only 0.2% of the vertices assigned to the landmarks. Second, the number of iterations required to find a solution with A decreased rapidly with increasing graph size. This is confirmed by Lemma 1, as the number of iterations required by A decreased with an improved estimate of the optimal cost to achieve the goal. In the second experiment, we observed that the effectiveness of euclidean distance heuristics decreased rapidly with increasing clutter, while the landmark heuristics responded much less sensitively to P (clear). This is summarized in Figure 5, where the number of symbols required by 20 decreased the number of hayristics while the number of the predefined by 7 decreased the number of symbols.

sections.heading: V. ROBOT MANIPULATOR EXAMPLE
sections.text: In order to demonstrate the suitability of trend-setting heuristics for realistic manipulator models, we use a model of the Jaco manipulator with six degrees of freedom from Kinova Robotics. In order to simulate a complex design task, the arm must find collision-free movement through a window that ends with the end effector at ground level to simulate the achievement of an object. The trend-setting heuristics was implemented in the Open Motion Planning Library (OMPL) [11] and the problem was solved with the MoveIt software tool [12]. Two overall objectives were considered for this problem: a goal with the shortest path and a minimum mechanical working goal. The motivation for using the shortest path target is that euclidean distance is available as a permissible heuristic method. On the other hand, minimizing the mechanical work required to perform the movement is a more natural goal, the closest to the movement, a minimum mechanical goal and a working goal.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION

referenceMentions.context: The probabilistic roadmap (PRM) [1] is a cornerstone of robot motion planning.

Applicability to multi-query problems is one of the advantages of the PRM over tree-based planners such as Rapidly exploring Random Trees (RRT) [2] and Expansive Space Trees (EST) [3] which are tailored to single-query problems.

Applicability to multi-query problems is one of the advantages of the PRM over tree-based planners such as Rapidly exploring Random Trees (RRT) [2] and Expansive Space Trees (EST) [3] which are tailored to single-query problems.
Highly parallelized feasibility checking using FPGAs was recently developed in [4] to alleviate this computational bottleneck during the construction phase.
The sparse roadmap spanner was introduced in [5] to reduce memory required to store the PRM and speed up the query phase by keeping only a sparse subgraph with near-optimality properties.
The landmark heuristic was originally developed for vehicle routing problems in road networks [6] where many shortest path queries are solved on a single graph.
The following optimal motion planning problem will be addressed: Let Xfree be an open, bounded subset of R, and Γ the set of continuous curves from [0, 1] to R.
The cost function must be additive in the sense that if two curves γ1,2 ∈ Γ satisfy γ1([0, 1]) ⊂ γ2([0, 1]) then c(γ1) ≤ c(γ2).

The PRM∗ method [7] is a popular variation of the PRM because it generates a sparse graph with the following property: if x0 and xg belong to a connected subset of Xfree, then for any fixed ε > 0, the probability that the PRM∗ graph contains a curve γ̂ ∈ Γfree satisfying

The results of this demo can be reproduced with the implementation of the landmark heuristic available in [8].

The landmark heuristic was implemented in the Open Motion Planning Library (OMPL) [11] and the problem was solved using the MoveIt [12] software tool.

metadata.abstractText: A landmark based heuristic is investigated for reducing query phase run-time of the probabilistic roadmap (PRM) motion planning method. The heuristic is generated by storing minimum spanning trees from a small number of vertices within the PRM graph and using these trees to approximate the cost of a shortest path between any two vertices of the graph. The intermediate step of preprocessing the graph increases the time and memory requirements of the classical motion planning technique in exchange for speeding up individual queries making the method advantageous in multi-query applications. This paper investigates these trade-offs on PRM graphs constructed in randomized environments as well as a practical manipulator simulation. We conclude that the method is preferable to Dijkstra’s algorithm or the A∗ algorithm with conventional heuristics in multi-query applications.
